Justification: To assess overall health and detect a variety of disorders, such as anemia, infection, and many other diseases.
To evaluate kidney function, blood sugar levels, and electrolyte and acid/base balance.
To assess cardiovascular risk by measuring cholesterol levels.
To screen for kidney disease and other health conditions.
To ensure normal thyroid function, as thyroid disorders can be asymptomatic.
To ensure no chronic viral infections, especially important for employment in certain sectors.
To rule out HIV infection, which is a standard part of many pre-employment screenings.
To rule out any underlying respiratory conditions, especially if the job involves physical activity or exposure to respiratory hazards.
To assess heart health, especially if there is a family history of heart disease or if the job is physically demanding.
